description: From Middle English vowe, voue, that from Old French vut, in turn from Latin vōtum (“a promise, dedication, vow”), from vovēre (“to promise, vow”).  Not related to avow. Doublet of vote.

entries.meaning: A solemn promise to perform some act, or behave in a specified manner, especially a promise to live and act in accordance with the rules of a religious order.
examples: The old hermit, up in the mountains, took a vow of silence.
There are also waxen vows, that represent other parts of the body mixed with them; but of these there are few in comparison of the number of the Priapi.

verbs.description: vow (third-person singular simple present vows, present participle vowing, simple past and past participle vowed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make a vow; to promise.
examples: When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it.

entries.meaning: To declare publicly that one has made a vow, usually to show one's determination or to announce an act of retaliation.
examples: The rebels vowed to continue their fight.
